natural problem: A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students. If one student is absent from school, the sections can all have the same number of students. What is the sum of all possible numbers of students enrolled at the school?
natural solution: If there are $s$ students, then $s-1$ must be divisible by 6. In other words, we want to find the sum of all values of $s$ for which $s-1\equiv 0\pmod{6}$. The multiples of 6 in the given range are 150, 156, ..., 198, so the possible values of $s$ are 151, 157, ..., 199.
Recalling that the sum of an arithmetic series is  \[ \frac{(\text{first term}+\text{last term})(\text{number of terms})}{2}, \]we find that these integers sum to $(151+199)(9)/2=\boxed{1575}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and S :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S = {n. 150 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 200 \<and> (\<exists> k. n = 6 * k + 1)}"
shows  "sum id S = 1575"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students. If one student is absent from school, the sections can all have the same number of students. What is the sum of all possible numbers of students enrolled at the school? The final Answer is 1575
 ### Proof
 If there are $s$ students, then $s-1$ must be divisible by 6. In other words, we want to find the sum of all values of $s$ for which $s-1\equiv 0\pmod{6}$. The multiples of 6 in the given range are 150, 156, ..., 198, so the possible values of $s$ are 151, 157, ..., 199.
 Recalling that the sum of an arithmetic series is  \[ \frac{(\text{first term}+\text{last term})(\text{number of terms})}{2}, \]we find that these integers sum to $(151+199)(9)/2=\boxed{1575}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: int and S :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S = {n. 150 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 200 \<and> (\<exists> k. n = 6 * k + 1)}"
shows  "sum id S = 1575"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of all integers from 150 to 200 inclusive that can be written in the form $6k+1$ for some integer $k$. The final answer is 1575.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: nat
assumes h0 : "150 \<le> students \<and> students \<le> 200"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (students - 1) mod 6 = 0"
shows  "sum students {students. 150 \<le> students \<and> students \<le> 200} = 1575"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students. If one student is absent from school, the sections can all have the same number of students. What is the sum of all possible numbers of students enrolled at the school? The final Answer is 1575
 ### Proof
 If there are $s$ students, then $s-1$ must be divisible by 6. In other words, we want to find the sum of all values of $s$ for which $s-1\equiv 0\pmod{6}$. The multiples of 6 in the given range are 150, 156, ..., 198, so the possible values of $s$ are 151, 157, ..., 199.
 Recalling that the sum of an arithmetic series is  \[ \frac{(\text{first term}+\text{last term})(\text{number of terms})}{2}, \]we find that these integers sum to $(151+199)(9)/2=\boxed{1575}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: nat
assumes h0 : "150 \<le> students \<and> students \<le> 200"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (students - 1) mod 6 = 0"
shows  "sum students {students. 150 \<le> students \<and> students \<le> 200} = 1575"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: The number of students is between 150 and 200 inclusive. If you subtract one from the number of students, the result is divisible by 6. What is the sum of all possible values of the number of students? The final answer is 1575.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_students :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "total_students = {x. 150 <= x \<and> x <= 200}"
and h1 : "\<forall>x \<in> total_students. ((x - 1) mod 6 = 0)"
shows  "sum id total_students = 1575"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students. If one student is absent from school, the sections can all have the same number of students. What is the sum of all possible numbers of students enrolled at the school? The final Answer is 1575
 ### Proof
 If there are $s$ students, then $s-1$ must be divisible by 6. In other words, we want to find the sum of all values of $s$ for which $s-1\equiv 0\pmod{6}$. The multiples of 6 in the given range are 150, 156, ..., 198, so the possible values of $s$ are 151, 157, ..., 199.
 Recalling that the sum of an arithmetic series is  \[ \frac{(\text{first term}+\text{last term})(\text{number of terms})}{2}, \]we find that these integers sum to $(151+199)(9)/2=\boxed{1575}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_students :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "total_students = {x. 150 <= x \<and> x <= 200}"
and h1 : "\<forall>x \<in> total_students. ((x - 1) mod 6 = 0)"
shows  "sum id total_students = 1575"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider a set of students with a total size between 150 and 200 inclusive. If for every size in this range the remainder when one less than the size is divided by 6 is zero, what is the sum of all such possible sizes? The final answer is 1575.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 150"
and h1 : "n \<le> 200"
and h2 : "6 divides (n - 1)"
shows  "sum id {n. n \<ge> 150 \<and> n \<le> 200 \<and> 6 divides (n - 1)} = 1575"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students. If one student is absent from school, the sections can all have the same number of students. What is the sum of all possible numbers of students enrolled at the school? The final Answer is 1575
 ### Proof
 If there are $s$ students, then $s-1$ must be divisible by 6. In other words, we want to find the sum of all values of $s$ for which $s-1\equiv 0\pmod{6}$. The multiples of 6 in the given range are 150, 156, ..., 198, so the possible values of $s$ are 151, 157, ..., 199.
 Recalling that the sum of an arithmetic series is  \[ \frac{(\text{first term}+\text{last term})(\text{number of terms})}{2}, \]we find that these integers sum to $(151+199)(9)/2=\boxed{1575}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<ge> 150"
and h1 : "n \<le> 200"
and h2 : "6 divides (n - 1)"
shows  "sum id {n. n \<ge> 150 \<and> n \<le> 200 \<and> 6 divides (n - 1)} = 1575"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the sum of all natural numbers between 150 and 200 (inclusive) that are one more than a multiple of 6. The final answer is 1575.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes students :: "nat set" and sections :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "students \<subseteq> {150..200}"
and h1 : "\<forall> s \<in> students. s mod 6 = 1"
shows  "sum id students = 1575"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students. If one student is absent from school, the sections can all have the same number of students. What is the sum of all possible numbers of students enrolled at the school? The final Answer is 1575
 ### Proof
 If there are $s$ students, then $s-1$ must be divisible by 6. In other words, we want to find the sum of all values of $s$ for which $s-1\equiv 0\pmod{6}$. The multiples of 6 in the given range are 150, 156, ..., 198, so the possible values of $s$ are 151, 157, ..., 199.
 Recalling that the sum of an arithmetic series is  \[ \frac{(\text{first term}+\text{last term})(\text{number of terms})}{2}, \]we find that these integers sum to $(151+199)(9)/2=\boxed{1575}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes students :: "nat set" and sections :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "students \<subseteq> {150..200}"
and h1 : "\<forall> s \<in> students. s mod 6 = 1"
shows  "sum id students = 1575"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: The set of students contains natural numbers from 150 to 200. Each student number, when divided by 6, leaves a remainder of 1. What is the sum of all the student numbers? The final answer is 1575.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "150 <= n \<and> n <= 200"
and h1 : "\<forall> m. m \<in> {150..200} \<and> m mod 6 = 1 \<longrightarrow> n = m"
shows  "sum n {150..200} = 1575"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students. If one student is absent from school, the sections can all have the same number of students. What is the sum of all possible numbers of students enrolled at the school? The final Answer is 1575
 ### Proof
 If there are $s$ students, then $s-1$ must be divisible by 6. In other words, we want to find the sum of all values of $s$ for which $s-1\equiv 0\pmod{6}$. The multiples of 6 in the given range are 150, 156, ..., 198, so the possible values of $s$ are 151, 157, ..., 199.
 Recalling that the sum of an arithmetic series is  \[ \frac{(\text{first term}+\text{last term})(\text{number of terms})}{2}, \]we find that these integers sum to $(151+199)(9)/2=\boxed{1575}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "150 <= n \<and> n <= 200"
and h1 : "\<forall> m. m \<in> {150..200} \<and> m mod 6 = 1 \<longrightarrow> n = m"
shows  "sum n {150..200} = 1575"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the sum of all natural numbers from 150 to 200 inclusive that are congruent to 1 modulo 6. The final answer is 1575.

a_6.formal problem:
Theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "150 <= n"
and h1 : "n <= 200"
and h2 : "\<exists>k. n - 1 = 6 * k"
shows  "sum_list [n\<leftarrow>[150..200]. \<exists>k. n - 1 = 6 * k] = 1575"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students. If one student is absent from school, the sections can all have the same number of students. What is the sum of all possible numbers of students enrolled at the school? The final Answer is 1575

 Recalling that the sum of an arithmetic series is  \[ \frac{(\text{first term}+\text{last term})(\text{number of terms})}{2}, \]we find that these integers sum to $(151+199)(9)/2=\boxed{1575}$.
 *)

Theorem
fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "150 <= n"
and h1 : "n <= 200"
and h2 : "\<exists>k. n - 1 = 6 * k"
shows  "sum_list [n\<leftarrow>[150..200]. \<exists>k. n - 1 = 6 * k] = 1575"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the sum of all integers from 150 to 200, inclusive, that are one more than a multiple of 6. The final answer is 1575.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "150 \<le> n"
and h1 : "n \<le> 200"
and h2 : "\<exists> k. n = 6 * k + 1"
shows  "sum id {n. 150 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 200 \<and> (\<exists> k. n = 6 * k + 1)} = 1575"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students.  *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "150 \<le> n"
and h1 : "n \<le> 200"
and h2 : "\<exists> k. n = 6 * k + 1"
shows  "sum id {n. 150 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 200 \<and> (\<exists> k. n = 6 * k + 1)} = 1575"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the sum of all natural numbers between 150 and 200 (inclusive) that can be written in the form $6k + 1$ for some natural number $k$. The final answer is 1575.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "150 ≤ n"
and h1 : "n ≤ 200"
and h2 : "∃ k. n = 6 * k + 5"
shows  "setsum id {n. 150 ≤ n ∧ n ≤ 200 ∧ (∃ k. n = 6 * k + 5)} = 1575"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students. If one student is absent from school, the sections can all have the same number of students. What is the sum of all possible numbers of students enrolled at the school? The final Answer is 1575
 ### Proof
 If there are $s$ students, then $s-1$ must be divisible by 6. In other words, we want to find the sum of all values of $s$ for which $s-1\equiv 0\pmod{6}$. The multiples of 6 in the given range are 150, 156, ..., 198, so the possible values of $s$ are 151, 157, ..., 199.
 Recalling that the sum of an arithmetic series is  \[ \frac{(\text{first term}+\text{last term})(\text{number of terms})}{2}, \]we find that these integers sum to $(151+199)(9)/2=\boxed{1575}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "150 ≤ n"
and h1 : "n ≤ 200"
and h2 : "∃ k. n = 6 * k + 5"
shows  "setsum id {n. 150 ≤ n ∧ n ≤ 200 ∧ (∃ k. n = 6 * k + 5)} = 1575"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Calculate the sum of all numbers between 150 and 200, inclusive, that can be expressed as 6 times some number k plus 5. The final answer is 1575.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_students :: int and sections :: int
assumes h0 : "150 <= total_students"
and h1 : "total_students <= 200"
and h2 : "sections = 6"
and h3 : "\<exists> absent_student. total_students - absent_student mod sections = 0"
shows  "∑ total_students = 1575"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A school has between 150 and 200 students enrolled. Every afternoon, all the students come together to participate in gym class. The students are separated into six distinct sections of students. If one student is absent from school, the sections can all have the same number of students. What is the sum of all possible numbers of students enrolled at the school? The final Answer is 1575
 ### Proof
 If there are $s$ students, then $s-1$ must be divisible by 6. In other words, we want to find the sum of all values of $s$ for which $s-1\equiv 0\pmod{6}$. The multiples of 6 in the given range are 150, 156, ..., 198, so the possible values of $s$ are 151, 157, ..., 199.
 Recalling that the sum of an arithmetic series is  \[ \frac{(\text{first term}+\text{last term})(\text{number of terms})}{2}, \]we find that these integers sum to $(151+199)(9)/2=\boxed{1575}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_students :: int and sections :: int
assumes h0 : "150 <= total_students"
and h1 : "total_students <= 200"
and h2 : "sections = 6"
and h3 : "\<exists> absent_student. total_students - absent_student mod sections = 0"
shows  "∑ total_students = 1575"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that the total number of students is between 150 and 200 and that the number of sections is 6. There is a certain number of absent students such that when subtracted from the total number of students, the result is divisible by the number of sections. Find the total number of students such that the sum of all students is 1575.
